Expectation1: Meet sales targets set by management
Situation1: On the final day of the quarter, the team must hit the cumulative target to avoid penalties and secure bonuses.
Expectation2: Arrive on time for scheduled volunteer shifts
Situation2: Several other volunteers can easily cover the first part of the shift if someone shows up a little late.
Story: The clock on my desk blinked 4:45 p.m. as I dialed another number, my headset pressing into my ear. My manager’s words echoed in my mind: “We’re just three sales short of the target. Every call counts.” I could almost feel the weight of my team’s hopes, the bonuses we’d all been working toward for months. But my phone buzzed with a reminder—my volunteer shift at the shelter started in fifteen minutes. I’d promised to be there on time, to help serve dinner, and I knew the staff counted on me to set an example. Still, I also knew that tonight, a few extra hands wouldn’t make or break the shift; the other volunteers could cover until I arrived. My stomach twisted as I stared at the phone, torn between the urgent pressure to keep calling and the quiet responsibility waiting for me across town. I could hear the voices of my coworkers and the shelter staff in my head, each expecting me to put them first. My hand hovered over the phone, heart pounding, as I wrestled with which promise to keep.
